text:
Nicky Morgan MP warns "hard Brexit" will fuel intolerance and bigotry By DavidWOwen   Bigotry warning: Loughborough MP Nicky Morgan is campaigning for "soft Brexit" and close EU ties Nicky Morgan MP warns "hard Brexit" will fuel intolerance and bigotry   
Loughborough MP Nicky Morgan is warning that a swing to the right in the UK's relations with Europe will lead to increased bigotry. 
The former education secretary, who was removed from office by Prime Minister Theresa May this summer, is set to spell out her thoughts at the Tory party conference, which kick's off on Sunday. 
The Conservative Party is set for a fierce debate in Birmingham this week on whether the UK should stay a member of the single market . 
Extracts from a speech Mrs Morgan will give to later today to the Conference fringe have been seen by the Observer newspaper. 
They reveal she believes that giving into Eurosceptic demands for a 'hard Brexit' – including quitting the single market completely and cutting all ties – will foster intolerance and bigotry. 
Instead, she is backing a policy of staying close to the EU and the single market, which would involved accepting immigration. 
She said: "There are some who interpret the June 23 vote as giving a licence to harsher rhetoric and returning to policies which have been rejected in the past. 
"Who seem to want to return to the days we spoke to ourselves rather than the public at large. 
"There are already those for whom the referendum result is not enough – they want us to have a 'hard Brexit' that cuts us off from the EU, turns our back on the single market and allows people to say things about their fellow citizens that promote intolerance and bigotry." 
Mrs Morgan will also warn Tory activists against a lurch to the right, using the Republican Tea Party and the emergence of Donald Trump in America as a lesson. 
She said: "The next general election is not in the bag and we have many, many marginal seats to defend and more to gain. 
"Look at what happened to the moderate mainstream Republicans in America who didn't defend their views against a Tea Party-led lurch to the right – eventually they ended up with Donald Trump as their candidate." 
The Prime Minister Theresa May is due to give her keynote speech to the conference on Wednesday.
